children.subject:
Actually, am EECS. We have breadth requirements too! (Only a few, but we do need breadths).
Also I've already taken EE16A, and EE16B so technically I do not need to take 54. Math 53, however, is an Engineering requirement regardless of major)
You mentioned a breadth so I assume you're CS and not EECS? If so, you take 54, not 53
Just wondering if you know if either 61c or 53 will offer alternative exams to resolve the exam conflict. I’m in a similar situation

I did not attend Math 53 lectures and still did well in the course. The concepts are not extremely difficult and the professor followed the textbook closely. If you attend a discussion and do the homework you should be fine.

Would advise you to start watching lectures / reading texts now, either 61C or 170. They are both available from past websites / Piazzas with a little bit of searching. In my experience, starting courses over the break helps a ton if you aren't already familiar with the material (which would defeat the point of the course).

history.content:
Hello everyone, 

So, I have settled on this schedule but there seems to be a scheduling conflict between 61C lecture, and Math 53 lecture since both are offered on Tuesdays/Thursdays from 5-6:30 PM. It's necessary that I finish these three techs this coming semester so I can potentially graduate on time (For context, am a junior  so probably you understand where am coming from. It's a long story). Anyway, my question is directed to people who've taken classes with conflicting schedules before, and how they did it. I was thinking of maybe attending all Math 53 lectures, and basically just watch the 61C webcasts. However, past experience dictates that class attendance (in my own experience) is incredibly necessary to do well so in this regard, I feel more conflicted than ever (Summer classes are not an option for me since I plan on doing an internship this coming summer). Do you think it's possible to self-study for Math 53 and still do well in the class? I understand that CS170 and CS61C are going to be really challenging, and time intensive but I believe everyone in EECS/CS has had at least one semester where they've had to fit in a higher course load than usual in a semester (For me, this might just be it). What are your opinions on this before I proceed to jump into the incoming storm?

Thank you!
history.subject: CS 170 + CS 61C + Math 53 and a 3 unit breadth (Professional Communication)
